containers.label: Vancouverian Forest
containers.tooltip: Maritime forests dominated by conifer species. Varying precipitation. Fir, Hemlock and Spruce varieties are prominent.

containers.label: Rocky Mountain Forest
containers.tooltip: Inland forests where conifer species are common. Includes dry and alpine climate zones. Fir, Pine, Juniper, and Hemlock varieties are prominent.

containers.label: Utah Pinyon Forest
containers.tooltip: Woodland/Scrubland characterized by the presence of Pinyon and Juniper varieties.

containers.label: California Forest
containers.tooltip: Dry upland forests characterized by broad-leafed deciduous trees and conifers. Oak, Pine, Fir varieties are prominent.

containers.label: Harvested/Burned Forest
containers.tooltip: Forest land that has been affected by logging, wildfires, or other disturbances.

containers.label: Freshwater Marsh/Bog
containers.tooltip: Riparian and swamp shrublands with shallow water and a variety of herbaceous vegetation.

containers.label: Salt Marsh
containers.tooltip: Wetlands with salinity of at least 0.5 ppt. Characterized by fluctuating water levels.

containers.label: Scrubland/Grassland
containers.tooltip: Includes both cool-temperate grassland and Mediterranean chaparral shrubland.

containers.label: Desert/Semi-Desert
containers.tooltip: Occurs in dry, cool-temperate climates, dominated by low shrubs. Sagebrush varieties are prominent.

containers.label: Alpine Tundra
containers.tooltip: Occurs at high elevations in mountain ranges.

containers.label: Agriculture/Introduced
containers.tooltip: Includes agricultural areas, as well as areas of non-agricultural introduced vegetation.

legend.description: Vegetation type based on 2011 USGS GAP Analysis data.

facts: &#9900 As of 2011, the Douglas Fir was the most logged tree in the Pacific Northwest.
&#9900 In 2017, over 1.8 million acres of forest were affected by wildfires.

legend.title: Change in Forest Cover
legend.description: Change in forest cover between. Total forest cover from 2000, forest gain from 2000 to 2012, and forest loss from 2000 to 2017. Forest loss includes both human and anthropogenic causes.

facts: &#9900 Scientific name: Pseudotsuga menziesii.
&#9900 Can grow between 70 and 330 ft. tall. Larger specimens are found in the Coast Range.
&#9900 State tree of Oregon.
&#9900 Not considered a true fir, such as Grand Fir or Subalpine Fir.

legend.title: Douglas Fir Basal Area (Sq Ft./Acre)
legend.description: Basal area represents the cross section (square footage) of tree trunks at the base over an acre.

facts: &#9900 Scientific name: Tsuga heterophylla.
&#9900  Can grow between 165 and 240 ft. tall.
&#9900 State tree of Washington.
&#9900 Extremely shade tolerant, and able grow under the canopies of larger trees, such as Douglas Fir or Sitka Spruce.

legend.title: Western Hemlock Basal Area (Sq Ft./Acre)
legend.description: Basal area represents the cross section (square footage) of tree trunks at the base over an acre.

facts: &#9900 Scientific name: Pinus ponderosa.
&#9900 Can grow over 200 ft. tall.
&#9900 Two subspecies of Ponderosa Pine are present within the PNW: Pacific Ponderosa and Columbia Ponderosa.

legend.title: Ponderosa Pine Basal Area (Sq Ft./Acre)
legend.description: Basal area represents the cross section (square footage) of tree trunks at the base over an acre.

facts: &#9900 Scientific name: Abies grandis.
&#9900 Can grow between 120 and 210 ft. tall.
&#9900 In the logging industry, Grand Fir is known as 'hem fir'.
&#9900 Commonly used as a Christmas tree.

legend.title: Grand Fir Basal Area (Sq Ft./Acre)
legend.description: Basal area represents the cross section (square footage) of tree trunks at the base over an acre.

facts: &#9900 Scientific name: Pseudotsuga menziesii.
&#9900 Can grow between 70 and 330 ft. tall. Larger specimens are found in the Coast Range.
&#9900 State tree of Oregon.
&#9900 Not considered a true fir, such as Grand Fir or Subalpine Fir.

legend.title: Juniper Basal Area (Sq Ft./Acre)
legend.description: Includes basal area of Western Juniper, Utah Juniper, and Rocky Mountain Juniper. Basal area represents the cross section (square footage) of tree trunks at the base over an acre.

facts: &#9900 Scientific name: Artemisia.
&#9900 Big Sagebrush and its subspecies are the most widespread sagebrush varieties in the PNW.
&#9900 Important for a variety of native species, including Sage Grouse, Pronghorn, and Mule Deer.

legend.title: % Sagebrush Cover
legend.description: Percent of landscape covered by sagebrush.

geographic.title: Vegetation Type:
geographic.description: Data from 2011. Raster data downloaded for each state and merged.

geographic.title: Forest Cover, Gain, and Loss:
geographic.description: The following datasets were downloaded: Global forest cover gain 2000–2012, Year of gross forest cover loss event, Tree canopy cover for year 2000.

geographic.title: Tree Species:
geographic.description: Species basal area, square feet/acre. RDS-2013-0013_RasterMaps_s10-s350.zip and RDS-2013-0013_RasterMaps_s601-s825.zip were downloaded. Datasets based on FIA species codes.

geographic.title: Sagebrush:
geographic.description: % Sagebrush datasets were downloaded and combined across 3 regions: Columbia Plateau/Blue Mountains, Wyoming/Montana/Black Hills, and Great Basin.

text.title: Sandberg Bluegrass, Needle-and-Thread Drawings:
text.description: USDA-NRCS PLANTS Database / Hitchcock, A.S. (rev. A. Chase). 1950. Manual of the grasses of the United States. USDA Miscellaneous Publication No. 200. Washington, DC.

basemap.title: Background Terrain:
basemap.description: ESRI Background Terrain; Source: USGS, Esri, TANA, DeLorme, and NPS. More information can be found
